description: Variant of cord, with spelling alteration due to Latin chorda (“cord”), ultimately from Ancient Greek (Doric) χορδά (khordá), (Ionic) χορδή (khordḗ, “string of gut, the string of a lyre”)

entries.meaning: (music) A harmonic set of three or more notes that is heard as if sounding simultaneously.
(geometry) A straight line between two points of a curve.

definitionGroups.group: (engineering) A horizontal member of a truss.

entries.meaning: (rail transport) A section of subsidiary railway track that interconnects two primary tracks that cross at different levels, to permit traffic to flow between them.
(aeronautics) The distance between the leading and trailing edge of a wing, measured in the direction of the normal airflow.
(nautical) An imaginary line from the luff of a sail to its leech.
(computing) A keyboard shortcut that involves two or more distinct keypresses, such as Ctrl+M followed by P.
The string of a musical instrument.
(graph theory) An edge that is not part of a cycle but connects two vertices of the cycle.

verbs.description: chord (third-person singular simple present chords, present participle chording, simple past and past participle chorded)

examples: This note chords with that one.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide with musical chords or strings; to string; to tune.
examples: When Jubal struck the chorded shell.
